Award.AwardTitle: Capacity building: Preparing Today's Scientists to Become Tomorrow's Teachers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Preparing Today's Scientists to be Tomorrow's Teachers proposes to build capacity by developing a large-scale sustainable partnership with seven high-need school districts, three STEM focused high school programs, the Mobius Science Center, non-profit programs for youth, and local STEM industries. The outcomes expected through this partnership are: (1) development of new curricula for both a STEM track in the awardee institution's existing Master in Teaching and Evening Teacher Certification programs and also new courses (called Step-Up) at the undergraduate level to ease the way into graduate level work, (2) development and implementation of informal science opportunities during the academic year and summer to encourage freshmen and sophomores to consider teaching, and (3) design of the infrastructure needed for recruitment, selection, data base tracking and induction activities necessary to support an application for a Track 1, Phase 1 Noyce project.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of the development of a STEM track in the graduate teacher preparation program lies in a research-based curriculum that spans multiple effective pedagogies from both formal to informal. Developing skill in multiple pedagogies provides teachers with the ability to teach well in differing environments.

Broader Impacts : The broader impact of multiple pedagogical experiences, being designed by this capacity building project, will be highly qualified teachers capable of teaching in a variety of educational environments and inspiring a new generation of students to pursue STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Whitworth University utilized the NSF-Noyce funds to meet three objectives: 1) research and design graduate STEM teacher education curriculum and increase graduate STEM teacher candidates; 2) increase the number of STEM majors choosing to teach through community outreach in academic courses, and summer internships to teach informal science; and 3) strengthen the collaboration between science faculty and education faculty through collaboration, trainings, and joint visits to secondary schools. Within the Master in Teaching program two STEM methods courses for secondary teachers were developed and piloted, including a 3-credit course entitled STEM Teaching: Concepts, Models and Literacy, and a 1-credit course in STEM Methods: Project-Based Instruction and Learning. An informal science teaching curriculum was developed for undergraduate STEM majors, and summer internship placements secured at a science center, Girl Scouts science camp, Boys and Girls Club, and an outreach center for the public library. A Computer Science methods course was developed with additional grant funding from OSPI, and a Computer Science Outreach course taught with internships in secondary schools teaching coding and computer science.  These are in alignment with the new Washington State Computer Science endorsement. Whitworth STEM and Education faculty and students attended three presentations from external experts on how students learn science, including presentations on interactive teaching and conceptual development in STEM, computer science education research on using pair-programming, peer instruction, and mindset theory, and how students learn Chemistry.  STEM faculty participated in a reading group to discuss evidence-based science pedagogy. STEM and Education faculty attended a summer workshop where local STEM high schools and community-based organizations presented sessions on best practices in both formal and informal STEM settings. An NSF Scholars after school STEM program was developed, with STEM undergraduates presenting to secondary students at a high-needs high school who are considering pursuing STEM majors in college.  Project faculty researched programs such as U-Teach to explore possible models.  As a part of the project's interest in project based learning methodology and with university funds, the project screened the film “Most Likely to Succeed” for the Washington State School Board and community educators.
